newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Cambodia marks third anniversary of constitution.
newsitem.headline: Cambodia marks third anniversary of constitution.

text.p: Cambodia on Tuesday marked the third anniversary of the signing of a constitution that restored the monarchy and promoted democracy after years of strong-arm rule.

Royal portraits, bunting and constitutional slogans adorned the public buildings of the capital, but for many Cambodians there was little reason to celebrate a document that has often been violated or ignored by the government, politicians and analysts said.

"For the ruling elite, the constitution is a piece of paper that exists only to legitimise their regime," an international human rights worker said. "It is something that facilitates rule, rather than governing rule."
Politicians say a barrier to enforcing the constitution has been a lack of laws and institutions to police the government.
Most notably, the formation of a constitutional council is long overdue, and parliament deputies worry that without that body, there is little hope of living up to the spirit of the constitution.

"There has been no interest from any major party to create (the council), so the laws being passed by parliament are not properly checked for (compliance with) the constitution," said Son Chhay, a Buddhist Liberal Democratic Party deputy.
Om Radsady, a deputy with the royalist FUNCINPEC party, said the issue of a constitutional council has been mired in politics for too long.
"We always have these kinds of political games," he said. "Before the next elections (in 1998), we must make setting up the constitutional council our priority."
There are other barriers looming over the promise of the constitution and Cambodia's first democratic elections in 1993.
The government has failed to set up an independent judiciary, a strong legal framework or even a royal council to appoint ageing King Norodom Sihanouk's successor.
Analysts said the lack of safeguards had seen former finance minister Sam Rainsy expelled from FUNCINPEC and then parliament in June last year for his repeated criticism of the government.

They also cited the case of Prince Norodom Sirivudh, a top FUNCINPEC member and half-brother of the king who was exiled last December on charges linked to an alleged assassination plot against Second Prime Minister Hun Sen.

Cambodia's human rights record, including the murders of several journalists, has come under fire from organisations like Amnesty International, which also criticised the recent amnesty for Khmer Rouge dissident Ieng Sary.

The foreign rights worker, who asked not to be named, said the lifting of Ieng Sary's 1979 death sentence for his role in the genocidal 1975-79 Khmer Rouge regime revealed conflicting aspects of the constitution, which simultaneously upholds the policy of reconciliation and respect for human rights.
"The amnesty for Ieng Sary is a classic dilemma of peace versus justice," the official said. "And that dualism is reflected in the constitution."
While they acknowledge the constitution lacks teeth, some government officials say expectations must be tempered after more than 20 years of civil war and decades of instability.
The 1993 constitution is Cambodia's seventh since World War Two, and they say it will take time to realise its vision.
The gap between the constitution's ideals and reality was clear in the lack of palace fanfare surrounding the anniversary.
When asked what was in store for the third anniversary of the constitution on Tuesday, palace official Oum Weakchiravuth said, "No party, nothing."
